body:
@benstopford Can you take a look at this?

There have been intermittent failures in this test where the offset on the leader indicates that all messages were not published successfully. The test was using retries=5, acks=0. If one of the brokers doesn't yet have the topic in its metadata cache when a message is published, publish fails with UNKNOWN_TOPIC_OR_PARTITION, but with acks=0, this doesn't result in a retry. I have changed acks=1 to fix the problem. Is there any reason why you would want acks=0 in the test?
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.1.
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.1.

@dguy I found the problem. Basically I think there some core classes that are affected by the type argument we introduced to `StateStoreSupplier` class. For example, `Stores` is one of them. So I think it is necessary to scan all occurrences of particular class and change the code to have some type argument to be safe. Please correct me if I am wrong.

@Mabin-J I just noticed a similar problem. My quick fix was simply to change "ps ax" to "ps axww" to force ps to print the entire command line. A similar fix is also necessary for zookeeper-server-stop.sh
Anyof @guozhangwang @hjafarpour @enothereska @dguy @miguno
@becketqin Thanks for the patch. Another thing I noticed is that we don't have a null check for the map passed to `offsetsForTimes`. Do you think it's worth adding one?

Another approach I was thinking is that the caller of tryCompleteElseWatch() shouldn't really need to hold any lock whiling calling it since the tryComplete thing is for async processing. In this particular case, we hold a group lock in GroupCoordinator.maybePrepareRebalance(), which will eventually call GroupCoordinator.tryCompleteJoin(), which acquires the group lock again. We could just release the group lock before calling GroupCoordinator.tryCompleteJoin().

In general, if we follow this protocol when using tryCompleteElseWatch(), we can avoid the deadlock w/o changing the watcher implementation.

@hachikuji I am not sure. I checked on the other methods such as `seekToBeginning()`, `resume()`, `pause()`. It seems that null pointer is not checked there either. I do not feel strongly on this because either NPE or IllegalArguementException will be thrown. But maybe we want to have the same behavior for all the interfaces?

@becketqin We do have null checks in `subscribe` and `assign`, so it's not like there's no precedent (as usual, it's difficult being consistent on these things). Speaking generally, I think an explicit check and an `IllegalArgumentException` with a clear message is a better user experience and a safer practice than depending on the code to raise an NPE. That said, let's not block the patch on this if you'd rather consider it separately.
LGTM. Merging to trunk and 0.10.1.
@hachikuji Thanks. Yes, I think it is probably clearer to the users to have an IllegalArgumentException with a message. Let's do it in a separate patch for all the interfaces.

This is a good start. We should eventually evaluate logging.   Scala 2.10 has macros so you can do very efficient logging calls as well.

We could use https://github.com/typesafehub/scala-logging or write our own.
Thanks again for the comments. Mostly addressed. Additional test is pending.

@isolis, Kafka still supports Scala 2.10, so we can't use `scala-logging`. It's probably more work than it's worth to write our own macros for that at this point. Maybe once we drop support for Scala 2.10.

@ijuma I did a quick test a while ago of a way to use macros with scala. It was more of a feasibility test than a real test.   Macros require a separate package so you need a 2 phase compile.  Using scala-logging might be a better option.

It's not urgent, obviously nobody is blocked by it, but at some point we should revisit this.  Some of our profile data was showing up to 6% of the time was spent on logging, but most of it is probably on these short lived classes and they way they instantiate logging (which this patch tries to work towards).  Once this is addressed the remaining part might be minor; so at some point the 0.5% performance improvement is not worth the added complexity.
LGTM

Merged to trunk and 0.10.1 branch.

@hachikuji : Thanks for the patch. Thinking about this a bit more. It seems that we could also deadlock between the lock on the delayed operation and the application lock (e.g., group). For example, in DelayedOperation.tryCompleteElseWatch(), we call the following.

operation synchronized operation.tryComplete()

In DelayedOperation.checkAndComplete(), we call the following

```
    else if (op synchronized op.tryComplete())
```

So, it's possible for thread1 to hold a group lock and wait for the operation lock when calling tryCompleteElseWatch(), and thread2 to hold the operation lock and wait for the group lock (in tryComplete()) when calling checkAndComplete().

Not sure what's the best way to fix that.

@junrao Interesting point. For the case of the heartbeat and join delayed operations, the synchronization at that level seems unnecessary since the `tryComplete` callbacks are already protected by the group lock. So maybe it is possible to move that synchronization into the abstract `DelayedOperation` itself so that its behavior can be overridden.

Yes, the intention of synchronizing on operation inside DelayedOperationPurgatory when calling tryComplete() is that the implementor of the delayed operation doesn't have to worry about synchronization. We could try not to do that. But then every implementation of DelayedOperation has to worry about synchronization, which may be more error prone.

Another approach is that we could just bite the bullet and restructure the group coordinator logic such that it doesn't hold the group lock when calling tryCompleteElseWatch().
For discussion, here is what I had in mind: https://github.com/apache/kafka/compare/trunk...hachikuji:refactor-delayed-operation-synchronization?expand=1.
Hmm, does that help? We still synchronize on operation before calling tryComplete().
I've overridden `safeTryComplete` for `DelayedHeartbeat` and `DelayedJoin`, so these operations will just depend on the group lock.

Chatted with Jun offline on this issue, and from the thread dump it seems one culprit is the handler thread handling a fetch request then trying to complete those delayed produce request due to HW advanced could actually trigger the `putOffsets` callback for those delayed produce that is actually for the offset topic. If this is THE only place we are trying to grab the locks in different order (i.e. for all other cases we are grabbing the group lock first, then calling purgatory's APIs in which we try to grab the operation lock; but for this case we grab the operation lock first, then inside `tryComplete` or `onComplete` we are grabbing other locks like the group lock) maybe we can consider treating this type of special delayed produce request differently, such that we can use a different purgatory which is "not thread safe" (i.e. this can be a constructor function parameter when creating the purgatory), hence callers need to make sure that the `tryComplete` and `onComplete` are all serialized, which is the case in group coordinator.
About `suppress`: I did enable "auto remove for unnecessary" in Intellij, which seems not to work correctly. Will revert those changes.
+1 (I don't have access to a windows machine but Radai did verify on his machine)

Nice catch. Due to KAFKA-3915, we don't want to convert messages in the cleaner any more. I think the fix should be something like:

``` scala
diff --git a/core/src/main/scala/kafka/log/LogCleaner.scala b/core/src/main/scala/kafka/log/LogCleaner.scala
index 3d9a20d..719afc4 100644
--- a/core/src/main/scala/kafka/log/LogCleaner.scala
+++ b/core/src/main/scala/kafka/log/LogCleaner.scala
@@ -401,7 +401,7 @@ private[log] class Cleaner(val id: Int,
         val retainDeletes = old.largestTimestamp > deleteHorizonMs
         info("Cleaning segment %s in log %s (largest timestamp %s) into %s, %s deletes."
             .format(old.baseOffset, log.name, new Date(old.largestTimestamp), cleaned.baseOffset, if(retainDeletes) "retaining" else "discarding"))
-        cleanInto(log.topicAndPartition, old, cleaned, map, retainDeletes, log.config.messageFormatVersion.messageFormatVersion, log.config.maxMessageSize)
+        cleanInto(log.topicAndPartition, old, cleaned, map, retainDeletes, log.config.maxMessageSize)
       }

       // trim excess index
@@ -439,7 +439,6 @@ private[log] class Cleaner(val id: Int,
    * @param dest The cleaned log segment
    * @param map The key=>offset mapping
    * @param retainDeletes Should delete tombstones be retained while cleaning this segment
-   * @param messageFormatVersion The message format version to use after compaction
    * @param maxLogMessageSize The maximum message size of the corresponding topic
    */
   private[log] def cleanInto(topicAndPartition: TopicAndPartition,
@@ -447,7 +446,6 @@ private[log] class Cleaner(val id: Int,
                              dest: LogSegment,
                              map: OffsetMap,
                              retainDeletes: Boolean,
-                             messageFormatVersion: Byte,
                              maxLogMessageSize: Int) {
     var position = 0
     while (position < source.log.sizeInBytes) {
@@ -495,7 +493,7 @@ private[log] class Cleaner(val id: Int,
           if (writeOriginalMessageSet)
             ByteBufferMessageSet.writeMessage(writeBuffer, entry.message, entry.offset)
           else
-            compressMessages(writeBuffer, entry.message.compressionCodec, messageFormatVersion, retainedMessages)
+            compressMessages(writeBuffer, entry.message.compressionCodec, entry.message.magic, retainedMessages)
         }
       }

@@ -518,7 +516,7 @@ private[log] class Cleaner(val id: Int,

   private def compressMessages(buffer: ByteBuffer,
                                compressionCodec: CompressionCodec,
-                               messageFormatVersion: Byte,
+                               outerMessageFormatVersion: Byte,
                                messageAndOffsets: Seq[MessageAndOffset]) {
     require(compressionCodec != NoCompressionCodec, s"compressionCodec must not be $NoCompressionCodec")
     if (messageAndOffsets.nonEmpty) {
@@ -529,13 +527,13 @@ private[log] class Cleaner(val id: Int,
       var offset = -1L
       val timestampType = firstMessageOffset.message.timestampType
       val messageWriter = new MessageWriter(math.min(math.max(MessageSet.messageSetSize(messages) / 2, 1024), 1 << 16))
-      messageWriter.write(codec = compressionCodec, timestamp = magicAndTimestamp.timestamp, timestampType = timestampType, magicValue = messageFormatVersion) { outputStream =>
-        val output = new DataOutputStream(CompressionFactory(compressionCodec, messageFormatVersion, outputStream))
+      messageWriter.write(codec = compressionCodec, timestamp = magicAndTimestamp.timestamp, timestampType = timestampType, magicValue = outerMessageFormatVersion) { outputStream =>
+        val output = new DataOutputStream(CompressionFactory(compressionCodec, outerMessageFormatVersion, outputStream))
         try {
           for (messageOffset <- messageAndOffsets) {
             val message = messageOffset.message
             offset = messageOffset.offset
-            if (messageFormatVersion > Message.MagicValue_V0) {
+            if (message.magic > Message.MagicValue_V0) {
               // The offset of the messages are absolute offset, compute the inner offset.
               val innerOffset = messageOffset.offset - firstAbsoluteOffset
               output.writeLong(innerOffset)
```

Does that seem right to you?

Something to consider: how do we fix messages affected by this bug?
We want to backport this to 0.10.0 as well.
cc @junrao
@ijuma trivial cleanup related to duplicate doc headers.  it is there is 0.10.1.0 docs
@ijuma Thanks :)

~~By the way, I think this should also be an issue with a message set containing a single message right? I think part of the problem is that `checkLogAfterAppendingDups` only checks the key and value. But ideally it would validate offsets and timestamps too. If we did the former, I think this bug would have been found then.~~

Edit: Ah, the issue is that we only call `compressMessages` if there is at least one message that is not retained in the message set. And if there is a single message in the message set, that means that there is nothing left to write (`compressMessages` is a no-op in that case).
Great improvement for huge clusters!

I've updated the PR to avoid the message conversion entirely. I guess the main question remaining is whether we should attempt to fix the log if a user has a log corrupted by this bug. To do this, I think we'd need to pass a flag into `deepConverter` so that it can avoid raising the `IllegalStateException` and adjust offsets as necessary. I'll try it out and see what it looks like.
@enothereska @guozhangwang @mjsax
LGTM
Lgtm

The long-term correct solution to the bug is still a wire format change.
However, shorter term this PR makes the code rely on InputStream.available() to detect EOF without catching an exception. this works because for this particular case the reads are all memory-backed (as opposed to directly from socket) and so all input is at hand - all that's required is careful implementation of available().
LGTM. Merged to trunk and 0.10.1.
Many thanks @dguy , sharp catch!
